intro: Ophiala, commonly known as the ghost plant, is a genus of aquatic plants belonging to the family Hydrocharitaceae. These plants are characterized by their slender, thread-like leaves that float on the water surface, often giving them a ghostly appearance. Ophiala species are typically found in slow-moving freshwater environments such as ponds and lakes. They play a role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat for small organisms and contributing to water filtration. The genus includes several species, with Ophiala tenera being one of the most commonly studied.
